body: Can vouch that the changes work on my end!
this looks great! very much in line with what i was thinking

After examining the structure of the chained prompts (e.g. self ask with search & ReAct & Natbot), I think a less opinionated approach to the structure of the examples (e.g. a list of examples as strings rather than a list of examples as dicts with specific key-value pairs) is more likely to generalize across all prompts. I think the value of a list of examples is 1) readability 2) dynamically omitting an example if my input to the prompt is too long. I don't think we need to be too opinionated about the key/value pairs in the examples as we're already trusting the user to structure their prompt templates correctly... we don't want to make it too onerous to fit every example into the key/value input_variables + output_suffix paradigm. I'll push an update which simply accepts examples as a list.

Pushed an example with the ReAct template... not quite sure how best to work in the example sizing into the Chain class.
Option 1: Add a num_examples argument to the __call__() method which takes a splice of the list of examples and uses that to initialize prompt in the _run() method. This feels like it muddies up the interface a bit, and also requires knowledge of the examples themselves and how long they are.
Option 2: Add a dynamic_prompt_sizing=True argument to the config, which detects if a prompt edges towards the token limit (or receives an over token limit error from an LLM) and automatically cuts an example. This feels like it might be a bit too magical / hiding too much config from the user.
Option 3: Explicitly let the user choose to use the example splicing in any further classes they define, and don't integrate it into the classes here.
Option 4: ?? Am I missing anything here?

yeah i like the change to go to whole examples. we can also do both! expose different constructor methods depending on the use case

related to your last point around incorporating dynamic examples, what do you think about just having a different prompt class? this prompt class could be like `DynamicPrompt`, and could take in init a list of examples, and then the dynamic removal of examples (if necc) comes into play when you call `.format`?

potentially theres two separate ideas/prs here:

- make it easy to specify a prompt from examples (what currently is here)
- make a separate dynamic prompt class (in follow up pr)

makes sense! I like the idea of adding a DynamicPrompt in a separate PR.
I forgot to add the 3rd reason for having an explicit list of examples (which originally motivated my comment about this over text haha) -- making it easier to generate test data more easily.

trying to test this locally & getting a weird error around openai import, have you seen this before? in both jupyter notebook & vanilla python shell, I get an error about openai import from pydantic, but can run import openai myself with no issues.
aha! found the issue in the root_validator for the OpenAIEmbeddings class, I think you need to add matplotlib explicitly to requirements.txt

ok, i finally got it to work by adding
matplotlib
plotly
scipy 
sklearn
explicitly to requirements.txt
one comment about the error message that threw me... otherwise this is great I want to use it right away!!

> trying to test this locally & getting a weird error around openai import, have you seen this before? in both jupyter notebook & vanilla python shell, I get an error about openai import from pydantic, but can run import openai myself with no issues. hmmm i have not seen
@hwchase17 Would love to contribute to this. did you have a specific implementation/interface in mind?

re: implementation; to be honest, not exactly. i haven't played around with elasticsearch in a while, and never with pinecone.

re: interface; my hope was that they could expose a similar interface to the FAISS class (https://github.com/hwchase17/langchain/blob/master/langchain/faiss.py) - in particular, the `similarity_search` method
hm im having trouble replicating. what version of `google-search-results` are you using? `pip show google-search-results`
messed up the git state a bit initially but think i fixed it with the branch force push

Would like to work on adding support for HF models. I think it is more convenient to use sentence_transformers as they can handle both sentence transformers and models coming from HF by adding a mean pooling layer. What do you think?
Version: 2.4.1
I'm getting the same error. V 2.4.1.
i think thats a great idea!

So NLTK's sentence and word tokenizers are pretty robust and fast. I'm curious to know how to observe its effectiveness

(Leaving the [module link here](https://github.com/hwchase17/langchain/blob/master/langchain/text_splitter.py) for easy reference)
Is there a reference or example on how this could work?
Great. I'll work on it
if you have any questions about the right place to put it or the conventions, happy to take a look at any even half-implemented stuff! just lmk
also added callable for returning length attribute of prompt

basically a wrapper on this (https://github.com/hwchase17/langchain/blob/master/examples/embeddings.ipynb) that synthesizes the found documents to come up with an answer

i will actually probably tackle this this weekend (bc its blocking a demo i want to get out), but happy to pair it if you have time this weekend

I made an initial implementation where i tried to stay close to how the openai one is implemented. Please check in the link below. I don't like the part where i instiatiate SentenceTransformer class inside embed functions and would love to have some suggestions there. Thanks

https://github.com/issam9/langchain/blob/issam/hf_embeddings/langchain/embeddings/huggingface.py
am thinking of changing to use pydantic dataclasses to take advantage of the postinit stuff https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66571079/alter-field-after-instantiation-in-pydantic-basemodel-class

okay - i see a few edges in the search code, will work on fixing those. however, i am not quite sure why this is erroring for this particular question. could you try running https://colab.research.google.com/drive/19LKe4p0qUv8aemB9P3xMnoQwVJBGSNkb#scrollTo=FkHWIJlimHIE? is this exactly what you were running locally or are there any differences?
